source.author: Thompson, I.R.
source.title: Cardamine
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Thompson, I.R. (1996). Cardamine. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves and/or stems with simple hairs (sometimes requiring close inspection)
Leaves and stems glabrous or minutely papillose
Upper surface of leaves glabrous (pinna margins may be ciliate)
Upper surface of leaves with scattered hairs

Fruits erecto-patent to spreading (inclined at 45°-90° to rachis); terminal pinna of cauline leaves entire to trilobed; basal leaves few; seeds less than 1.0 mm long; base of stems often reddish-purple and hairy; weed of gardens and nurseries
Fruits suberect (inclined at less than 45° to rachis); terminal pinna of cauline leaves 3–9-lobed; basal leaves forming a rosette; seeds longer than 1 mm; stems usually green and glabrous

Leaves mostly with 0–2 pairs of lateral pinnae; flowering stems not held erect, often not developed; pedicels commonly arising in whorls of 3 or 4, sometimes appearing to arise singly from the base; fruits less than 1 mm wide; flowers often apetalous or with fewer than 4 petals
Leaves with 1–6 pairs of lateral pinnae; main flowering stem erect; pedicels alternating along rachis; fruits 1–1.5 mm wide; flowers usually 4-petalled

Stems sparsely to densely hairy; stamens mostly 6; fruits glabrous and spreading, inclined at greater than 45° to rachis and not or hardly overtopping open flowers of the same inflorescence; inflorescence rachis often flexuose; cauline leaves 2 or more, surface often tuberculate due to tubercle-based hairs

Stems glabrous to very sparsely hairy; stamens mostly 4; fruits glabrous or hairy, suberect, inclined at less than 45° to rachis and usually clearly overtopping open flowers in the same inflorescence; inflorescence rachis straight; cauline leaves 0–3, rarely more, surface not obviously tuberculate

Seeds 0.8–1.0 mm long; petals c. 3 mm long; basal leaves few, usually shorter than cauline leaves and not persisting; racemes many-flowered with fruits erecto-patent to spreading, inclined at 45°-90° to rachis; weed of gardens and nurseries
Seeds 1.0 mm long or more; plants not combining the above features; native species

Terrestrial plant with stoloniferous habit; basal leaves arising singly at intervals along horizontal stem, the stem turning upwards to form an erect, mostly unbranched, flowering stem; alpine or subalpine plant of damp or marshy sites
Non-stoloniferous species; basal leaves in a loose to distinct rosette; flowering stem more or less erect from base

Cauline leaves more than 6, although lower ones not persisting, and mostly with narrow to filiform pinnae projecting at right-angles to leaf rachis; mature style more than 1.5 mm long; petals more than 5 mm long; elongate plant of swampy habitats
Cauline leaves mostly fewer than 6, if the middle and upper cauline leaves have very narrow almost linear pinnae, then mature style less than 1.5 mm long; habitat various

Basal and cauline leaves simple and linear to narrowly spathulate, or often pinnately divided with 1-several linear lateral lobes projecting forwards and a much longer terminal lobe; annual plant with few-flowered racemes
Plants not as above
Leaves simple and ± spathulate, or if pinnately lobed, the terminal lobe elliptic and lateral pinnae somewhat obovate, sessile and with attenuate bases
At least some of the basal leaves pinnate, the terminal pinna (or blade of simple leaves) orbicular to ovate, often cordate at base, and most lateral pinnae distinctly stalked
Basal leaves sometimes with small lobes, but never pinnatisect; inflorescence up to 15-flowered; sepals 1–1.8 mm long; petals 2.5–4 mm long; lowland forests
At least some basal leaves pinnatisect; inflorescence up to 30-flowered (sometimes more); sepals 1.8–3 mm long; petals 4–7 mm long; subalpine areas
Plants with several subtuberous and distinctly tapering roots, arising from a short rootstock; petals 5–8 mm long
Plants not as above, petals 2–12 mm long
Seeds greater than 1.5 mm long; petals 4–12 mm long; perennial
Seeds 1.0–1.3 mm long; petals 2–6 mm long; annual or perennial
Terminal pinna of cauline leaves mostly 5 (or more)-lobed or -toothed, lateral pinnae usually also lobed or toothed, most pinnae with several minute cilia on margins
Terminal and lateral pinnae of cauline leaves entire or with one or two lateral lobes or teeth, pinnae not minutely ciliate on margins (but may be papillate)

Cauline leaves 0–3, the lowermost sometimes pinnate and similar to basal leaves, otherwise small (usually less than 2 cm long), reducing markedly in size up the stem; lateral pinnae of pinnate leaves orbicular, entire

Cauline leaves usually 3 or more, all pinnate to deeply pinnatisect (usually greater than 2 cm long) with overall leaf shape and size changing only gradually up the stem; lateral pinnae of basal and cauline leaves somewhat elliptic, entire or with one or two lateral lobes

Terminal pinna of basal leaves truncate-cuneate at base; pinnae usually markedly 2–3-lobed (if entire then very narrowly spathulate); mature style less than 1 mm long; raceme short, not shrivelling when pressed
Terminal pinna of basal leaves cordate at base; pinnae mostly entire to shallowly 2–3-lobed, broader than above; mature style 0.5–2 mm long; raceme condensed to lax, shrivelling when pressed
